Dated this the 4" day of August, 2016
ORDER

1.The petitioners herein are accused Nos.1 to 5 in
C.C.No.261 of 2014 on the file of the Judicial Magistrate of
First Class Court, Payyoli. The aforesaid case has arisen
from Crime No.297 of 2010 of Kuttiadi Police Station
registered for the offences punishable under Section 143,
147, 148, 160, 435, 427 read with Section 149 of the IPC
and under section 3(2)(e) of the PDPP Act.

2.After investigation, final report was laid before the
jurisdictional Court arraying 30 persons as the accused.
The petitioners were arrayed as 14, 22, 24, 26 and 30 in
the final report. The petitioners did not appear before the
court below and face the trial. The case was proceeded
against accused Nos.1 to 13, 15 to 21, 23, 25 and 27 to
29. They were found not guilty by the learned Magistrate

BREE
soakensants

Crl.M.C.4162/2016 2
and were acquitted under section 248(1) of the Code of
Criminal Procedure. (hereinafter referred to as the
“Code”).

3.The petitioners have preferred this petition under Section
482 of the Code seeking to quash the above proceedings
on the ground that the substratum of the case has been
shattered in view of the acquittal of the co-accused.

4.1 have heard the learned counsel for the petitioners as
well as the learned Public Prosecutor.

5.1 have given my _ anxious’ considerations to the
submissions made across the bar and I have also gone
through the materials on record. It is evident from
Annexure-II judgment of the court below that none of the
witnesses had supported the case of the prosecution. The
learned Additional Sessions Judge after evaluating the
prosecution evidence in a meticulous manner concluded
that there is no evidence to connect the accused with the
crime. The prosecution witnesses had gone to the extent

BREE
soakensants

Crl.M.C.4162/2016 3
of testifying that they were unaware as to the identity of
the persons who attacked them. These observations,
would definitely affect the very substratum of the
prosecution case. As held by this Court in Moosa v. Sub
Inspector of Police (2006 (1) KLT 552), though the
reasoning of the judgment contained or appreciation of
evidence in the case of a co-accused therein are not
grounds to attract any relief under Section 482 of the
Code, a case where the substratum of the case is lost is
an exception to the above rule.

6.1 am of the firm view that no purpose is going to be
served by directing the petitioners to face the trial at this
stage. It can only be a futile exercise and the only
purpose that will be served is to gnaw into precious time
during which more productive work can be done by the
court below. The prospects of conviction is extremely
remote owing to the acquittal of the co accused.

In the result, this petition is allowed. The proceedings
